data.description:
GovGraph is an innovative approach to visualizing and understanding the relationships within governance ecosystems. Unlike traditional scoring systems, GovGraph focuses on the connections and interactions between power users, such as Delegates, Developers, and Citizens. 

By mapping these relationships through a dynamic and interactive graph, users can identify alliances, conflicts of interest, and clusters of influence. The system allows for detailed filtering and searching, providing insights into social graphs, voting patterns, and potential sybil attacks. This project aims to enhance the transparency and efficiency of the governance and funding processes.

We’ll focus on the OP Citizen House first and then explore other governance systems.

For the CollabTech round:
- Desired threshold is $3k for the MVP (delivery ~Sep-Oct)
data.title: GovGraph

data.description:
GovGraph is an innovative approach to visualizing and understanding the relationships within governance ecosystems. Unlike traditional scoring systems, GovGraph focuses on the connections and interactions between power users, such as Delegates, Developers, and Citizens.


By mapping these relationships through a dynamic and interactive graph, users can identify alliances, conflicts of interest, and clusters of influence. The system allows for detailed filtering and searching, providing insights into social graphs, voting patterns, and potential sybil attacks. This project aims to enhance the transparency and efficiency of the governance and funding processes.


Try: https://op.govgraph.fyi/


Who has benefited most from the analytics work you have produced?

Here’s some feedback from various users:

  • Emily (OP Citizen House): this is very interesting! looks to me like I can use this to see the most connected people, who maybe also have the most influence... like vitalik and linda
  • Griff (Citizen, Delegate): It’s a fantastic tool for coordination in the Citizen House. Seeing the shared connections can greatly support planning and partnerships, as well as aid in checking for collusion.
  • Kevin Owocki (Citizen): seems like a nice way to get an at a glance view of the op political economy
  • Divine Comedian (Citizen): Tried it out, visually it looks cool
  • Luuk (OP Developer): That sounds great, we can add the graph to the Analytics page for sure. We’re also working on a second version of our website, which could have more sections about visualisations and maps
  • Alex Soto (OP governance contributor): I really like that there are different categories with which to filter the view and the level of interactivity it has. And yet, I miss categories more linked to the work within the collective (like ‘chosen in representative structures this season’ or ‘are part of x contribution path’); which is what I tried to reflect in my chart (we plan to add this feature soon)

Also accepted into Token Engineering the Superchain, Web3 Grants Ecosystem Advancement, CollabTech Round and Thresholds Experiment gitcoin rounds, got donations from 56 contributors. Got a small prize at the OP Superhack lately.
data.title: GovGraph

questions.query: Vision Statement and Impact: Describe the long-term vision of your project and its intended impact on the Optimism and broader Superchain ecosystem, including both qualitative and quantitative benefits
questions.explanation:
The long-term vision of GovGraph is to revolutionize the way governance ecosystems are understood and managed within the Optimism and broader Superchain ecosystem. By leveraging the power of graph-based data visualization, GovGraph aims to create a transparent, equitable, and efficient governance framework.

Qualitative Benefits

- Enhanced Transparency: By visualizing relationships and interactions within the governance ecosystem, stakeholders can gain a clearer understanding of how decisions are made and who holds influence.
- Improved Decision-Making: With insights into alliances, conflicts of interest, and influence clusters, decision-makers can make more informed choices that reflect the true dynamics of the ecosystem.
- Increased Trust: Transparent governance processes foster trust among participants, encouraging more active and engaged participation from a diverse range of stakeholders.

Quantitative Benefits

- Reduced Sybil Attacks: By identifying sybil entities through social graph analysis, GovGraph can help mitigate the risk of fraudulent activities, leading to a more secure and reliable governance system.
- Optimized Resource Allocation: Understanding voting patterns and influence clusters allows for more strategic allocation of resources, ensuring that funding and support are directed to the most impactful projects and initiatives.
- Enhanced Metrics for Governance Health: By tracking ongoing metrics such as voter clusters and high-influence participants, the system provides valuable data that can be used to continuously improve governance processes and maintain a balanced distribution of power.

questions.query: Initial Strategy: Outline a high-level strategy for how you will achieve your intended impact and key goals for the next 3-6 months
questions.explanation:
Phase 1: Research and Development (Months 1-2)

- Conduct Initial Research: Gather detailed requirements from key stakeholders and analyze existing governance systems.
- Develop MVP (Minimum Viable Product): Create a basic version of GovGraph focusing on core features such as graph visualization of user relations, filtering, and search functionalities.
- User Testing and Feedback: Engage with a group of early adopters (Delegates, Developers, Citizens) to test the MVP and gather feedback for improvements.

Phase 2: Feature Enhancement and Optimization (Months 3-4)

- Implement Feedback: Refine and enhance the MVP based on user feedback, focusing on usability improvements and additional features such as dynamic dispersion and color-coded connections.
- Expand Data Sources: Integrate additional data sources, including mainnet/testnet attestations and POAPs, to enrich the graph.
- Develop Advanced Analytics: Incorporate advanced analytics to identify governance attacks, voting patterns, and influence clusters.

Phase 3: Deployment and Scaling (Months 5-6)

- Rollout to Broader Audience: Launch GovGraph to a wider audience within the Optimism and broader Superchain ecosystem.
- Monitor and Iterate: Continuously monitor the system’s performance and user engagement, iterating on the product based on ongoing feedback.
- Establish Key Partnerships: Form strategic partnerships with other projects and organizations to enhance data integration and expand GovGraph’s impact.

questions.query: Team Expertise: Provide a brief summary on the team’s background and relevant expertise in token engineering and/or OP
questions.explanation: We’ll focus on the OP Citizen House first and then explore other governance systems. The product part of the team is Max Semenchuk and Yineisy Mota from https://trustedseed.org/ from the dev side it’s Alireza and Krati from https://www.generalmagic.io/

questions.query: Existing Work: Provide evidence of any existing work, such as prototypes, research papers, or previous projects. If you have already done work within OP/ Superchain, please include that here too
questions.explanation: Last year we’ve worked together on https://regenscore.super.site/ , overall GM has a wide experience with tools grants tooling including https://www.pairwise.vote/ In Trusted Seed we connect 360+ steward of various web3 commons.

data.title: Product review of Feb 2025

questions.query: How is the project CollabTech?
questions.explanation:
The idea of mapping the ecosystem was explored back in 2019 with the early DAOs / Genesis DAO etc: https://graphcommons.com/graphs/6a993e34-d8b0-4425-83ce-67c3560429e7?mode=connect back then it was a useful tool to explore the space and connect the dots. Now after some time, we plan to use a similar approach based on a variety of on-chain data to clusterize voters and build better strategies with those insights.

It can give visual insight and be a research tool for either building alliances or otherwise tracking conflicts of interest. There are a number of scoring practices that exist, but this experiment gives more qualitative data, showing less visible connections between voters & projects.

questions.query: Who's the targeted user group and what's the need/problem being addressed?
questions.explanation: We've had some requests from the foundation to learn more about the RetroPGF improvement. But also we see a need ourselves (and within our networks) as grantees to understand how to interact with the voters better. It's an experimental project, so we'll yet to see the amount if insight from it, but it should contribute to the transparency and efficiency of the grants ecosystem.

questions.query: How do you ensure value keeps being delivered after the round is over? (How will the project become commercially sustainable or a perennial good? )
questions.explanation: We could consider analytical services built on top of the tool, also building adaptations for various ecosystems

questions.query: How long will it take after funding is received to deliver value? (share a high level timeline)
questions.explanation: We plan to launch the first version of the tool at the end of August and use Sep-Oct to improve and collect community sentiment.

questions.query: How does your project contribute to the advancement of the Web3 grants ecosystem?
questions.explanation: Contributions to Web3 grants on-chain registry, Research on grant program design and effectiveness, Development of Web3 Grants tooling, Experiments with innovative funding mechanisms

questions.query: Describe your previous work or plans related to the Web3 grants ecosystem.
questions.explanation: The idea of mapping the ecosystem was explored back in 2019 with the early DAOs / Genesis DAO etc: https://graphcommons.com/graphs/6a993e34-d8b0-4425-83ce-67c3560429e7?mode=connect back then it was a useful tool to explore the space and connect the dots. Now after some time, we plan to use a similar approach based on a variety of on-chain data to cluster voters and build better strategies with those insights.

questions.query: How does your project create value for the Web3 grants ecosystem?
questions.explanation: It can give a visual insight and a research tool for either building alliances or otherwise tracking the conflict of interest. There are several scoring practices exist, but this experiment gives more qualitative data, showing less visible connections between voters & projects.

questions.query: Describe your team's expertise in your chosen focus area within Web3 grants. Include relevant experience, publications, or past projects.
questions.explanation:
The product part of the team is Max Semenchuk and Yineisy Mota from https://trustedseed.org/ from the dev side it’s Alireza and Krati from https://www.generalmagic.io/

Last year we’ve worked together on https://regenscore.super.site/ , overall GM has wide experience with tools grants tooling including https://www.pairwise.vote/ In Trusted Seed we connect 360+ steward of various web3 commons.

questions.query: How do you plan to share insights, methodologies, or tools developed through your project with the Cartographer Syndicate and the broader Web3 grants community?
questions.explanation: We’re planning to start with the OP citizen house analytics but than scale it further to other networks. With the the amount of data points tracked across various chains would allow to oversee the bigger governance space and learn better/faster as well as establishing the cross-chain reputation in governance and funding.
